STATIC_heading.text: ABBREVIATIONS

STATIC_table.text:
ADAlzheimer disease—a form of dementiaMAOImonoamine oxidase inhibitor; an example is phenelzine (Nardil)
ADHDattention-deficit/hyperactivity disorderMDDmajor depressive disorder
ADLsactivities of daily livingMMPIMinnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory
AIMSabnormal involuntary movement scale—used to monitor signs of tardive dyskinesiaNCDneurocognitive disorder
ASDautism spectrum disorderOCDobsessive-compulsive disorder (anxiety disorder)
BZDbenzodiazepineOCPDobsessive-compulsive personality disorder
CAchronologic agePTSDpost-traumatic stress disorder
CBTcognitive-behavioral therapyRxtherapy
CNScentral nervous systemSADseasonal affective disorder
DSM-5Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth EditionSNRIserotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; an example is duloxetine (Cymbalta)
DTdelirium tremensSSRIselective serotonin reuptake inhibitor; an example is fluoxetine (Prozac)
ECTelectroconvulsive therapyTATThematic Apperception Test
GADgeneralized anxiety disorderTCAtricyclic antidepressant
IDintellectual disabilityTDtardive dyskinesia
IQintelligence quotient
An IQ test is a standardized test to
determine mental age of an individual.
The average person is considered to
have an IQ of between 90 and 110.
Those who score below 70 are
considered to have an intellectual
disability.		THCdelta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol—active ingredient in marijuana
LSDlysergic acid diethylamide—a hallucinogenWAISWechsler Adult Intelligence Scale
MAmental age—as determined by psychological testsWISCWechsler Intelligence Scale for Children
  Ψsymbol for psych- (the uppercase Greek letter psi)
  ΨRxpsychotherapy
